Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue to challenge this deeply ingrained U.S. travel ethic by insisting on demanding respect and asserting their right to accept or reject boorish visitors' demands.

But these are two different cultures.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Universal’s Gothic aesthetic. Allen Dwan’s subtitles, calling for cross-cultural solidarity against racial bigotry even as they discriminate against Asians and Turks, are ever so close to Parker’s light shine training lyrics, but most of Parker’s other themes feel shoe horned in and underdeveloped. Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by its external look, people praising this movie haven't realised that. The biggest mistake to me is that : parody or not, this movie has taken a good literary character, prang it enough to make him looking like a psychopath. The movie doesn't have any climax, nor a conclusion
